intro: Gratiola virginiana f. acutidens, commonly known as the sharp-leaved goldenroot, is a flowering plant native to the eastern United States. It belongs to the family Apiaceae, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its slender, branched stems and small, yellowish-green flowers. The plant produces distinctive, kidney-shaped roots that are often used in traditional herbal medicine. Its leaves are narrow and pointed, giving it the "sharp-leaved" designation in its scientific name. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in woodland edges and along stream banks.
